bio: Usain Bolt, OJ, CD (born 21 August 1986) is a Jamaican sprinter. Regarded as the fastest man ever, he is the world record holder in the 100 metres, 200 metres and 4 × 100 metres relay. He is the reigning Olympic champion in these three events, the first man to win six Olympic gold medals in sprinting, and a nine-time World champion. He also holds the world record as a part of the 4 × 100 metres relay.

bio: The Heiress (1947 play) is a play by Ruth and Augustus Goetz based on the 1880 novel Washington Square by Henry James. It premiered on Broadway at the Music Box Theatre on October 2, 1947. The play was directed by Sidney Lumet and starred Wendy Hiller as Catherine Sloper and Basil Rathbone as Morris Townsend. The play was a critical and commercial success, and it won the Tony Award for Best Play.

bio: Rick and Morty is an American adult animated science-fiction sitcom created by Justin Roiland and Dan Harmon for Cartoon Network's late-night programming block Adult Swim. The series follows the misadventures of alcoholic scientist Rick Sanchez and his easily influenced grandson Morty Smith, who split their time between domestic family life and interdimensional adventures. bio: The Reader (2008 film) is a 2008 American-German historical romantic drama film based on the 1995 German novel of the same name by Bernhard Schlink. It is directed by Stephen Daldry and written by David Hare, based on the 1995 novel. The film stars Kate Winslet, Ralph Fiennes, David Kross, and Lena Olin. bio: Emily Ratajkowski is an American model and actress. Born to American parents in London and raised primarily in California, she began modeling at the age of 14. She rose to prominence in 2013 after appearing in the music video for Robin Thicke's "Blurred Lines", which became the most disliked video on YouTube at the time. She became a recurring character on the fifth season of the Nickelodeon series iCarly. Her modeling career has included working with brands such as Forever 21, Nordstrom, and Marc Jacobs. She has appeared on the cover of Cosmopolitan, GQ, and FHM. In 2015, she appeared in the Sports Illustrated Swimsuit Issue.

The film's title character is a sports agent who, after a mission statement he writes for his workplace goes viral, is fired and begins his own agency with only one client. bio: Baahubali: The Beginning is a 2015 Indian epic historical fiction film directed by S. S. Rajamouli and jointly produced by Shobu Yarlagadda and Prasad Devineni under the banner Arka Media Works. It is the first of two cinematic parts. The film stars Prabhas, Rana Daggubati, Anushka Shetty, Tamannaah, Ramya Krishnan and Sathyaraj. The film was shot in both Telugu and Tamil languages simultaneously. The film is the highest-grossing Indian film of all time.

bio: Newspaper is a serial publication containing news, other informative articles, and advertising. It usually appears on cheap, low-grade paper such as newsprint. It may also include other media such as photographs, maps, and other artwork. Newspapers are typically published daily or weekly. News magazines are also weekly, but they have a magazine format. General-interest newspapers typically publish news articles and feature articles on national and international news as well as local news. The news includes political events and personalities, business and finance, crime, weather, and natural disasters; health and medicine, science, and computers and technology; sports; and entertainment, society, food, and home cooking. Typically, the paper is divided into sections for each of those major groupings (called "sections", "editions", or "modules"). Most newspapers are businesses, and they pay their expenses with a mixture of subscription revenue, newsstand sales, and advertising revenue. The journalism organizations that publish newspapers are themselves often metonymically called newspapers.

bio: Alive 2006/2007 is a live album by American rock band Kiss, released on September 11, 2007. It was recorded in August 2006 and August 2007 during the band's 2006–2007 world tour, and was released in four different formats: a 2-disc CD, a 2-disc DVD, a 2-disc Blu-ray disc, and a limited edition box set. The album is the first Kiss live album to be released without the involvement of band co-founder Gene Simmons, who did not take part in the 2006–2007 tour.

bio: Brad Pitt (born William Bradley Pitt; December 18, 1963) is an American actor and film producer. He has received multiple awards and nominations including an Academy Award as producer under his own company Plan B Entertainment. Pitt first gained recognition as a cowboy hitchhiker in the road movie Thelma & Louise (1991). His first leading roles in big-budget productions came with the dramas A River Runs Through It (1992) and Legends of the Fall (1994), and the horror film Interview with the Vampire (1994). He gave critically acclaimed performances in the crime thriller Seven (1995) and the science fiction film 12 Monkeys (1995), the latter earning him a Golden Globe Award for Best Supporting Actor and an Academy Award nomination.

bio: Paramore (album) is the self-titled fourth studio album by American rock band Paramore, released on April 5, 2013, by Fueled by Ramen. The album was produced by Justin Meldal-Johnsen and Paramore, and co-produced by David Bendeth. bio: Muhammad Ali (born Cassius Marcellus Clay Jr.; January 17, 1942) is an American former professional boxer, activist, and philanthropist. He is widely considered one of the greatest boxers of all time, and was involved in several historic boxing matches. Notable among these were the "Fight of the Century", "The Rumble in the Jungle", and the "Thrilla in Manila". Ali was born and raised in Louisville, Kentucky, and began training as an amateur boxer at age 12. At age 22, he won a gold medal in the light heavyweight division at the 1960 Summer Olympics. After turning professional later that year, Ali went on to become the first boxer to win the lineal heavyweight championship three times. He successfully defended this title 19 times, including victories over some of the most celebrated heavyweights in history, such as Sonny Liston, George Foreman, Ken Norton, and Joe Frazier.

bio: Evan Rachel Wood is an American actress, model, and musician. She is the recipient of a Primetime Emmy Award and three Golden Globe Award nominations. Her early acting career included roles in the television series American Gothic (1995–96) and Once and Again (1999–2002). bio: One More Light is the fifth studio album by American rock band Linkin Park, released on May 19, 2017, through Warner Bros. Records. The album was produced by band members Mike Shinoda and Brad Delson, alongside producer Andrew Boyd. One More Light is a departure from the band's previous rock and alternative rock sound, as it features more elements of pop and electronic music. It was preceded by the singles "Heavy", "Battle Symphony", "Good Goodbye", "Talking to Myself", "One More Light", "Crawling" and "Sharp Edges".

bio: Mango (Mangifera indica) is a tropical fruit native to South Asia. The tree is a member of the cashew family Anacardiaceae, and the mango fruit is a drupe, a type of fleshy fruit. The mango is a popular fruit in many countries, with cultivation and consumption being widespread. The mango tree is a large evergreen tree that can grow to 35–40 m tall. The leaves are alternate, 15–35 cm long, pinnate, with three or more pairs of leaflets and a terminal leaflet. The flowers are perfect, with five free petals, and the fruit is a fleshy drupe. The mango fruit is oval in shape, with a greenish-yellow skin and a sweet, yellow-orange flesh.

bio: Social justice is a concept of fair and just relations between the individual and society. This is measured by the explicit and tacit terms for the distribution of wealth, opportunities for personal activity, and social privileges. Social justice often refers to the idea of creating a society or institution that is based on the principles of equality and solidarity, that understands and values human rights, and that recognizes the dignity of every human being. The term and modern understanding of "social justice" have been shaped by the work of JS Mill, Henry Sidgwick, and John Rawls.

bio: Robert Browning was an English poet and playwright whose mastery of dramatic verse, especially dramatic monologues, made him one of the foremost Victorian poets. His poems are known for their irony, characterization, dark humour, social commentary, historical settings, and challenging vocabulary. Browning's early career began promisingly, but was not a success. The long poem Pauline brought him lasting fame, and he married Elizabeth Barrett, who became his collaborator. Her death in 1861 was a deep blow, from which he never fully recovered.

bio: Tyra Banks (born December 4, 1973) is an American television personality, producer, author, actress, and former model. She first became famous as a model, appearing twice on the cover of the Sports Illustrated Swimsuit Issue and working for Victoria's Secret as one of their original Angels. Banks is the creator and host of the UPN/The CW reality television show America's Next Top Model, co-creator of True Beauty, and host of her own talk show, The Tyra Banks Show. In 2004, she became the first African American woman to be featured on the covers of GQ and the Sports Illustrated Swimsuit Issue, and in 2010, she became the host and executive producer of America's Next Top Model. She has also co-authored a young adult novel series titled Modelland.

bio: Conan O'Brien is an American television host, comedian, writer, and producer. He is best known for hosting several late-night talk shows; since 2010, he has hosted Conan on the cable channel TBS. O'Brien was born in Brookline, Massachusetts, and raised in an Irish Catholic family. He served as president of The Harvard Lampoon while attending Harvard University, and was a writer for the sketch comedy series Not Necessarily the News. After writing for several comedy shows in Los Angeles, he joined the writing staff of Saturday Night Live (SNL).

bio: Singapore, officially the Republic of Singapore, is a sovereign island country and city-state in maritime Southeast Asia. It lies about one degree (137 kilometres or 85 miles) north of the equator, at the southern tip of the Malay Peninsula, with Indonesia's Riau Islands to the south and Peninsular Malaysia to the north. Singapore's territory consists of one main island along with 62 other islets. Since independence, extensive land reclamation has increased its total size by 23% (130 square kilometres or 50 square miles). The country is known for its transition from third world to first world in a single generation under the leadership of its founding father, Lee Kuan Yew.

The screenplay by Lorenzo Semple Jr. and David Rayfiel was adapted from the 1974 novel Six Days of the Condor by James Grady. The film is known for its suspense and tension, and for being one of the first movies to use a high-definition video recording system (Philips Vidicon camera).

bio: French Open (French: Tournoi de Roland-Garros), also known as Roland-Garros (French: [ʁɔlɑ̃ ɡaʁos]), is a major tennis tournament held over two weeks between late May and early June at the Stade Roland Garros in Paris, France. It is the second of four Grand Slam tennis events held each year, the other three being the Australian Open, Wimbledon and the US Open. Roland Garros is the only major held on clay, and it is the zenith of the spring clay-court season.

bio: Evonne Goolagong Cawley, AO, MBE (born 31 July 1951) is a former World No. 1 tennis player from Australia. She won seven Grand Slam singles titles and was runner-up in another seven Grand Slam singles tournaments. She also won 14 Grand Slam women's doubles titles and two Grand Slam mixed doubles titles. She won a career Grand Slam in singles, which she achieved in 1980. She was the first Aboriginal Australian to win a Grand Slam title.

bio: Twitter is an American microblogging and social networking service on which users post and interact with messages known as "tweets". Registered users can post, like, and retweet tweets, but unregistered users can only read public tweets. Users interact with Twitter through browser or mobile frontend software, or programmatically via its APIs. Prior to April 2020, services were accessible via SMS. Twitter was created in March 2006 by Jack Dorsey, Noah Glass, Biz Stone, and Evan Williams, launched in July of that year, and the service rapidly gained worldwide popularity. In 2012, more than 100 million users posted 340 million tweets a day, and the service handled an average of 1.6 billion search queries per day. In 2013, it was one of the ten most-visited websites and has been described as "the SMS of the Internet". As of 2018, Twitter had more than 330 million monthly active users.

bio: Kim Basinger is an American actress and former fashion model. She was born in Athens, Georgia, and was raised in the nearby town of Braselton. She is the daughter of Ann Lee (née Cordell), a model, actress, and beauty queen who held the titles of Miss Georgia (1957) and Miss America (1958), and of Donald Wade Basinger, a big-band musician and entrepreneur. Basinger spent her early years in Athens, where her father had moved in the early 1960s to play big-band jazz in local clubs.

bio: David Bowie (born David Robert Jones; 8 January 1947 – 10 January 2016) was an English singer-songwriter and actor. A leading figure in the music industry, he is regarded as one of the most influential musicians of the 20th century. Bowie was acclaimed by critics and musicians, particularly for his innovative work during the 1970s. His career was marked by reinvention and visual presentation, his music and stagecraft significantly influencing popular music. During his lifetime, his record sales, estimated at over 140 million albums worldwide, made him one of the world's best-selling music artists. In the UK, he was awarded ten platinum, eleven gold and eight silver album certifications, and released 11 number-one albums. In the US, he received five platinum and nine gold certifications. He was inducted into the Rock and Roll Hall of Fame in 1996.

bio: Emmanuel Adebayor (born 26 February 1984) is a Togolese professional footballer who plays as a striker for Turkish club Kayserispor. Adebayor began his career with Metz, before moving to Monaco in 2003. He was signed by Arsenal in 2006, and was the club's top goalscorer in the 2007–08 season. In 2009, he moved to Manchester City in a transfer worth £25 million, making him the most expensive African footballer in history at the time. He also holds the record for the fastest Premier League hat-trick, scoring three times in the space of nine minutes against Derby County. He returned to Arsenal on loan in 2011, before signing permanently for Tottenham Hotspur in 2012. He had brief spells at Crystal Palace and Istanbul Başakşehir, before joining Kayserispor in 2018.

Phoenix played supporting roles in films such as Running on Empty (1988), I Love You to Death (1990), and My Own Private Idaho (1991). He was cast in the lead role of Sam in Interview with the Vampire (1994), but died of a drug overdose at the age of 23 before it was released.

bio: Bal Gangadhar Tilak (23 July 1856 – 1 August 1920) was an Indian nationalist, social reformer, teacher, and an independence activist. He was the first popular leader of the Indian Independence Movement and the architect of the Swaraj movement. He was also a Sanskrit scholar, mathematician, teacher and journalist. He was one of the first people to advocate for Swaraj (self-rule) as a means of securing independence from British rule. He also preached Swadeshi (self-sufficiency) and Boycott as means of resistance. He was also the first leader to give the slogan of "Swaraj is my Birthright and I shall have it".

bio: Renaissance is a 1985 album by English singer Annie Lennox, released by the label Arista Records. The album was released in the United Kingdom on 14 January 1985 and in the United States on 18 February 1985. It was Lennox's first solo album after the breakup of her group Eurythmics, and she produced it with Stephen Lipson. The album was a commercial success and sold over 1.5 million copies in the United States. It was also a critical success, and received two Grammy Awards. The album was supported by three singles: "Sweet Dreams (Are Made of This)", "Whole Lotta Love", and "Walking on Broken Glass".

bio: Agatha Christie was an English crime novelist, short story writer, and playwright. She also wrote romances under the name Mary Westmacott, but she is best known for the 66 detective novels and 14 short story collections she wrote under her own name, especially those featuring detectives Hercule Poirot or Miss Jane Marple. She also wrote the world's longest-running play, a murder mystery, The Mousetrap. In 1971 she was made a Dame by Queen Elizabeth II at Buckingham Palace. She died in 1976 after a career spanning more than half a century.

bio: Fight Club is a 1999 American film directed by David Fincher and starring Brad Pitt, Edward Norton, and Helena Bonham Carter. Based on the 1996 novel of the same name by Chuck Palahniuk, it follows the events of an anonymous everyman (Norton) who is discontented with his white-collar job. He forms a "fight club" with soap maker Tyler Durden (Pitt), and they are joined by men who also want to fight recreationally. The narrator becomes embroiled in a relationship with Durden and a dissolute woman (Bonham Carter) who may be Tyler's therapist, and the narrator and Durden may be facets of the same personality.

bio: Edgar Allan Poe (born Edgar Poe; January 19, 1809 – October 7, 1849) was an American writer, poet, editor, and literary critic, and is best known for his poetry and short stories, particularly his tales of mystery and the macabre. He is widely regarded as a central figure of Romanticism in the United States and of American literature as a whole, and he was one of the country's earliest practitioners of the short story. He is generally considered the inventor of the detective fiction genre and is further credited with contributing to the emerging genre of science fiction. He was the first well-known American writer to try to earn a living through writing alone, resulting in a financially difficult life and career.

bio: Northeast megalopolis, also known as the BosWash corridor, is a megalopolis in the northeastern United States stretching from Boston, Massachusetts, to Washington, D.C. It is the largest metropolitan area in the United States by population, with 45.7 million people as of 2015. The region is home to the highest concentration of wealth and corporate headquarters in the country, as well as the largest number of educational institutions. The area is also known for its extensive rail and highway networks, including the Northeast Corridor, the New Jersey Turnpike, the Long Island Expressway, and the George Washington Bridge.

bio: Jessica Chastain (born March 24, 1977) is an American actress and film producer. Born in Sacramento, California, Chastain developed an interest in acting from a young age. In 1998, she made her professional stage debut as Shakespeare's Juliet. She then moved to New York City to study acting, and later became a member of the Actors Studio. In 2004, she made her film debut in Jolene. In 2008, Chastain garnered a nomination for the Academy Award for Best Supporting Actress for her performance in the drama film, JESSICA CHASTAIN.

bio: Kangana Ranaut (born 23 March 1987) is an Indian actress and film director who works in Hindi films. She is the recipient of several awards, including three National Film Awards and four Filmfare Awards. She was awarded the Padma Shri in 2020. Born in Bhambla, Himachal Pradesh, Ranaut initially aspired to become a doctor at the insistence of her parents. Determined to build her own career path, she relocated to Delhi at 16, where she briefly became a model. After training under the theatre director Arvind Gaur, she shifted to Mumbai and signed a three-film deal with Anurag Kashyap in 2006.

bio: Soundgarden was an American rock band formed in Seattle, Washington, in 1984 by singer and rhythm guitarist Chris Cornell, lead guitarist Kim Thayil, and bassist Hiro Yamamoto. Matt Cameron became the band's full-time drummer in 1986, while bassist Ben Shepherd became a permanent replacement for Yamamoto in 1990. Soundgarden was one of the key bands in the creation of grunge, a style of alternative rock that developed in Seattle and was the subgenre that popularized alternative rock in the 1990s. Soundgarden was the first grunge band to sign to a major record label, as the band's original label Sub Pop signed the band in 1987. Soundgarden's third studio album, Badmotorfinger (1991), brought the band mainstream success, but it was their fourth album, Superunknown (1994), which brought the band international success.

bio: Daniel Craig (born 2 March 1968) is an English actor. He trained at the National Youth Theatre and graduated from the Guildhall School of Music and Drama in 1991, before beginning his career on stage. His films include Elizabeth, The Power of One, A Kid in King Arthur's Court, Lara Croft: Tomb Raider, Road to Perdition, Layer Cake, Munich, Infamous, Casino Royale, Quantum of Solace, Defiance, Cowboys & Aliens, The Adventures of Tintin, Dream House, The Girl with the Dragon Tattoo, Skyfall, Star Wars: The Force Awakens, Spectre, Logan Lucky, and Knives Out. Craig has also portrayed James Bond in five films: Casino Royale (2006), Quantum of Solace (2008), Skyfall (2012), Spectre (2015), and No Time to Die (2021).

bio: Purple Haze is a song written by Jimi Hendrix and released as the second record on the 1967 album Are You Experienced. It is one of his best-known songs and is considered a psychedelic rock anthem. The song is written in the key of E minor and is played in 4/4 time at a tempo of approximately 120 beats per minute. The song is known for its opening chord, which is widely considered to be one of the greatest rock guitar intro riffs. The song was ranked number 17 on Rolling Stone's list of the 500 Greatest Songs of All Time.

bio: Nikita (TV series) is an American action crime drama television series that aired on The CW from September 9, 2010, to December 27, 2013, in the United States. The series is a remake of the 1990 French film Nikita by Luc Besson. The series was officially picked up on May 19, 2010. The series follows Nikita, who is a spy working for a secret government organization called Division. She is on a mission to destroy the organization, which is led by Percy, her former handler. The series was created by Craig Silverstein and was produced by Warner Bros. Television and CBS Television Studios. Maggie Q stars as Nikita, with Lyndsy Fonseca, Shane West, Aaron Stanford, Melinda Clarke, and Xander Berkeley in supporting roles.

bio: Republic of Ireland is a sovereign state in north-western Europe occupying 26 of 32 counties of the island of Ireland. The capital and largest city is Dublin, which is located on the eastern side of the island, and whose metropolitan area is home to around a third of the country's 4.7 million inhabitants. The state shares its only land border with Northern Ireland, a part of the United Kingdom. It is otherwise surrounded by the Atlantic Ocean, with the Celtic Sea to the south, Saint George's Channel to the south-east, and the Irish Sea to the east. The country is a member of the European Union and is a founding member of the Council of Europe and the OECD.
